docs.snippet: What happens to a democracy when you mix trolls, disinformation and a populist strongman?
Researchers have found evidence that Russian-language or Kremlin-linked Twitter accounts pushed divisive messages in British politics, too.

headline.print_headline: Signs That Russia Used Social Media to Sway Brexit Vote
headline.main: Signs of Russian Meddling in Brexit Referendum

docs.snippet: A Times examination of Russian-linked Facebook pages used in the 2016 election found that much of the content was taken directly from videos and posts from Americans.

headline.print_headline: Russians Spun American Rage Into a Weapon
headline.main: How Russia Harvested American Rage to Reshape U.S. Politics

docs.snippet: Like a twisted version of the producers of an unscripted TV show, Kremlin-linked trolls used fake personas to provoke very real drama.

headline.print_headline: The Drama of Reality TV, Brought to You by Russia
headline.main: What Reality TV Teaches Us About Russia’s Influence Campaign

docs.snippet: Readers discuss what to do in the face of Russian efforts to sway voters in the 2016 election.
With Russian meddling making headlines, it’s trendy to bash social media companies. Instead, we should look in the mirror.

headline.print_headline: Silicon Valley Can’t Destroy Democracy Without Our Help
headline.main: Silicon Valley Can’t Destroy Democracy Without Our Help

docs.snippet: Lee Ming-cheh was sentenced to five years in prison in the first case in which China has convicted a Taiwanese citizen of state subversion.

headline.print_headline: China Convicts Taiwanese Human Rights Activist of Subversion
headline.main: China Sentences Taiwanese Human Rights Activist in Subversion Case

docs.snippet: Opposing the bill became difficult for the companies, which have been under harsh scrutiny in recent weeks.

headline.print_headline: In Reversal, Tech Titans Back Bill on Sex Trafficking
headline.main: In Reversal, Tech Companies Back Sex Trafficking Bill

docs.snippet: Many of the social network’s ad-targeting terms are legitimate in principle but can be problematic in practice. Consider, for instance, the word “confederate.”

headline.main: Facebook’s Ad-Targeting Problem, Captured in a Literal Shade of Gray

docs.snippet: Readers say “follow the money,” and call on tech companies to limit their news feeds to legitimate sources.
